questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine medical check-up. The patient feels well. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and recurrent panic attacks. He had a myocardial infarction 3 years ago. He underwent a left inguinal hernia repair at the age of 25 years. A colonoscopy 2 years ago was normal. He works as a nurse at a local hospital. He is married and has two children. His father died of prostate cancer at the age of 70 years. He had smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years but quit following his myocardial infarction. He drinks one to two beers on the weekends. He has never used illicit drugs. Current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, lisinopril, metoprolol, fluoxetine, metformin, and a multivitamin. He appears well-nourished. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a high-frequency, mid-to-late systolic murmur that is best heard at the apex. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary valve regurgitation manifests as a high-frequency, blowing murmur during diastole heard best at the 2nd left intercostal space. The location of the murmur at the apex and the occurrence during systole make this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve stenosis manifests as a low-frequency, mid-diastolic rumble and a loud S1 heard best at the apex. This patient has a systolic murmur, making this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

C) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid valve stenosis manifests as a low-frequency, mid-diastolic rumble heard best at the lower parasternal region. This patient has a systolic heart murmur, making this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Delayed diastolic murmur with a decrescendo, possible presystolic crescendo

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve regurgitation manifests as a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur that may radiate to the axilla and is best heard at the apex. While the location and the occurrence during systole of this patient's murmur may suggest mitral regurgitation, the timing (mid-to-late systole) makes this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

E) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid valve regurgitation manifests as a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur heard best at the lower parasternal region. While the occurrence during systole of this patient's murmur may suggest tricuspid regurgitation, the character, point of maximum intensity, and timing make this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

F) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve regurgitation manifests as a high-frequency, blowing decrescendo murmur during early diastole that is best heard at the left sternal border or the apex. This patient has a systolic murmur, suggesting a different answer option.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

G) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve stenosis manifests as a harsh mid-systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur that is typically heard best at the right upper sternal border, not at the apex.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

H) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary valve stenosis primarily manifests during early childhood as a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best at the 2nd left intercostal space. In adults, it may result from carcinoid syndrome or chronic rheumatic fever. The location of the murmur at the apex suggests another diagnosis.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

I) CORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse is the most common valvular abnormality in the US and is usually asymptomatic, as in this patient. It typically manifests as a high-frequency, midsystolic click combined with a high-frequency, mid-to-late systolic murmur heard best at the apex, which is consistent with this patient's auscultatory findings. Mitral valve prolapse is most often idiopathic, but can also be secondary to conditions such as rheumatic heart disease, infectious endocarditis, connective tissue disorders, or myocardial infarction (MI). Following MI, ischemia of the papillary muscles and subsequent rupture of the chordae tendinae may cause one or both mitral valve leaflets to prolapse into the left atrium, which leads to acute symptoms of regurgitation. Even though this patient has a history of MI, his asymptomatic presentation 3 years later suggests an idiopathic etiology.

See “Auscultation in valvular defects” table.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.
questions.hint: This type of murmur will typically occur earlier during systole and with increased intensity when the patient abruptly stands up from a squatting position or performs the Valsalva maneuver.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a well-child examination. He has been healthy and has met all developmental milestones. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 97th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. His vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Auscultation of the heart shows a high-frequency, midsystolic click that is best heard at the fifth left intercostal space. Oral examination shows a high-arched palate. He has atypically long, slender fingers and toes. The patient is asked to clasp the wrist of the opposite hand and the little finger and thumb overlap. Slit-lamp examination shows superotemporal lens subluxation bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Molecular genetic testing is indicated to rule out fragile X syndrome, which also presents with tall stature, hypermobile joints, and features of MVP. However, the absence of other key features like intellectual disability, delayed language development, long facies, large ears, and macroorchidism make the diagnosis unlikely. Although genetic testing can confirm the diagnosis of Marfan syndrome, the condition is a clinical diagnosis and any form of molecular/genetic testing is not indicated in a patient with classic features, as is the case here. Considering the clinical presentation, a different diagnostic procedure is more important in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Karyotyping is indicated if an underlying chromosomal disorder is suspected. This patient has MVP and is at the 97th percentile for height, which could be suggestive of Klinefelter syndrome. However, the rest of the physical examination findings (e.g., lens subluxation, joint hypermobility, arachnodactyly) cannot be explained by Klinefelter syndrome. For this reason, karyotyping would not be the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Echocardiography is indicated in patients with suspected Marfan syndrome to evaluate for cardiac or aortic disease (e.g., aortic root dilatation, aortic aneurysm, aortic dissection). These findings, if present, support the diagnosis of Marfan syndrome and are potentially fatal if left untreated. A midsystolic click at the cardiac apex is highly suggestive of MVP, which is commonly associated with connective tissue disorders such as Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. Treatment of MVP in asymptomatic patients is unnecessary.

Slit-lamp examination is the second most important diagnostic test in children diagnosed with Marfan syndrome. As in this patient case, it can reveal commonly associated ocular abnormalities (e.g., superotemporal lens dislocation, retinal detachment).

D) INCORRECT:

A thyroid biopsy is indicated for suspected thyroid cancer. Medullary thyroid carcinoma is associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia 2B (MEN 2B). This condition is often characterized by marfanoid body habitus (i.e., increased height, elongated limbs, and joint hypermobility), which is seen in this patient. However, the complete absence of any mucosal neuromas, which are generally the first clinical manifestation of MEN 2B, or any features of medullary thyroid cancer (e.g., thyroid nodule) or pheochromocytoma (e.g., hypertension, diaphoresis, tachycardia) makes this diagnosis unlikely.

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) develops in almost all patients with MEN 2. Therefore, if there is clinical suspicion for MEN 2 (i.e., at least two typical clinical findings), genetic testing should be performed, followed by measurement of the serum calcitonin and thyroid ultrasound to screen for MTC.

E) INCORRECT:

IGF-1 measurement may be indicated in a child with tall stature to detect excess growth hormone, which indicates gigantism. However, patients with gigantism usually exhibit much more rapid growth than this child. Moreover, gigantism is associated with other characteristics, such as coarse facial features, thickening of the fingers and toes, headaches, and visual changes (mass effect due to pituitary adenoma), and macrocephaly, which are all absent in this patient. IGF-1 measurement is therefore not indicated in this patient.

Acromegaly refers to abnormally high linear growth due to excessive IGF-I production after the growth plate cartilages have fused in adulthood. If the condition occurs before epiphyseal plate closure, it is referred to as gigantism.

F) INCORRECT:

An elevated plasma homocysteine concentration is diagnostic of homocystinuria. This condition typically manifests with a marfanoid body habitus (i.e., tall stature, long extremities, and arachnodactyly) and subluxation of the ocular lens, as seen in this child. However, the absence of thrombotic events (e.g., stroke), developmental delay, and intellectual disability make Marfan syndrome the more likely diagnosis. Furthermore, lens subluxation in homocystinuria usually occurs in a downward direction rather than superolaterally.
questions.hint: The combination of tall stature, a high-arched palate, arachnodactyly, a positive wrist sign, mitral valve prolapse (MVP), and lens subluxation (ectopia lentis) in the superotemporal direction strongly suggests Marfan syndrome.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 1-week history of difficulty breathing. He has had recurrent palpitations over the past 2 years. During this time, he has also had several episodes of anxiety despite no change in his daily life. He has occasional sharp chest pain localized to the left upper sternal border. He has no abdominal pain or leg swelling. Two years ago, he had streptococcal pharyngitis, which was promptly treated with a 10-day course of penicillin. He has never traveled outside of the country. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 3/6 holosystolic murmur that is loudest at the apex and radiates to the axilla with a mid-systolic click. Bilateral fine crackles are heard on lung auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ectopic production of serotonin occurs in carcinoid syndrome. In extraintestinal carcinoid tumors and carcinoid tumors that have metastasized to the liver, increased serotonin that bypasses hepatic first-pass metabolism and enters the right heart can lead to fibrotic degeneration of valves and, as a result, pulmonary valve or tricuspid valve disease (i.e., carcinoid heart disease). The left side of the heart (including the mitral valve) is very rarely affected because serotonin is broken down by pulmonary enzymes before entering the left atrium. This patient's murmur is best heard at the apex, which is not consistent with murmurs heard in right-sided valvular disease. Moreover, this patient lacks classic findings of carcinoid syndrome such as flushing, recurrent diarrhea, telangiectasia, and asthmatic wheezing.

B) CORRECT:

Myxomatous degeneration is caused by the accumulation of dermatan sulfate within the connective tissue of the mitral valve. In developed countries, it is the most common cause of mitral valve degeneration and subsequent mitral valve prolapse. As the disease course progresses, mitral regurgitation can occur. This patient presents with common features of mitral valve prolapse (palpitations, anxiety, chest pain, mid-systolic click). The new-onset dyspnea, holosystolic murmur, and crackles on lung auscultation are consistent with regurgitation of the mitral valve, indicating an advanced disease process.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

C) INCORRECT:

Calcification is a common degenerative process involving the mitral annulus that can, depending on the severity of calcification, result in mitral stenosis and/or regurgitation. However, in most cases, calcific valve degeneration is asymptomatic and only has a negligible influence on mitral valve function. It is the most common cause of aortic valve stenosis, not mitral valve regurgitation. Patients with aortic stenosis may present with exertional dyspnea, angina pectoris-like symptoms, and a systolic murmur. However, aortic valve stenosis often also manifests with exertional dizziness or syncope and causes a late systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur at the right upper sternal border that radiates bilaterally to the carotids, not a holosystolic murmur heard loudest at the apex.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

D) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory valve degeneration occurs in rheumatic heart disease, a late sequela of group A streptococcal infection, which often affects the mitral valve. Earlier stages of rheumatic heart disease most often involve mitral valve regurgitation, which then later develops into mitral stenosis. The pathogenesis of the disease involves cross-reactivity with group A streptococci (also referred to as molecular mimicry), which results in the development of autoimmune antibodies. While this patient has a history of streptococcal pharyngitis, he was adequately treated with penicillin, which makes rheumatic heart disease unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Excessive catecholamine release is seen in patients with pheochromocytoma. While patients with pheochromocytoma often have bouts of intense palpitations and elevated blood pressure, other common symptoms include pallor, throbbing headache, diaphoresis, and hypertensive crisis, which are absent in this patient. Furthermore, pheochromocytoma would not account for this patient's dyspnea and holosystolic murmur.
questions.hint: Dyspnea, a systolic murmur heard best at the cardiac apex that radiates to the axilla, and bilateral lung crackles on auscultation raise suspicion of pulmonary edema due to acute mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: A 25-year old man comes to the physician because of fatigue over the past 6 months. He has been to the emergency room several times over the past 3 years for recurrent shoulder and patella dislocations. Physical examination shows abnormal joint hypermobility and skin hyperextensibility. A high-frequency mid-systolic click is heard on auscultation. Which of the following is most likely to result in an earlier onset of this patient’s auscultation finding?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The characteristic click heard on auscultation in patients with mitral valve prolapse (MVP) results from the bulging of the valve leaflets into the atrium, which begins when the contracting left ventricle reaches a critical volume during systole. An increased left ventricular end-diastolic volume, e.g., due to increased afterload and subsequent increased left ventricular end-systolic volume during hand grip (hand clenching) delays the point when that volume is reached and results in a later onset of the auscultatory findings.

B) CORRECT:

The characteristic auscultatory finding of MVP is a high-frequency mid-systolic click, which is caused by sudden tensing of the chordae tendineae as the valve leaflets prolapse. The click may be followed by a mid-to-late systolic murmur indicating mitral regurgitation. Since the prolapse occurs when the contracting ventricle reaches a critical volume, the timing of the click varies according to the left ventricular end-diastolic volume (EDV). Decreased EDV, e.g., due to decreased venous return to the heart during abrupt standing (i.e., decreased preload) causes the leaflets to prolapse sooner, resulting in an earlier onset (i.e., closer to S1) and increased intensity of auscultatory findings. Conversely, maneuvers that increase the volume (e.g., squatting) result in a later onset and decreased intensity.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

The characteristic click heard on auscultation in patients with mitral valve prolapse (MVP) results from the bulging of the valve leaflets into the atrium, which begins when the contracting left ventricle reaches a critical volume during systole. An increased left ventricular end-diastolic volume, e.g., due to increased venous return to the heart during rapid squatting (i.e., increased preload) delays the point when that volume is reached and results in a later onset of the auscultatory findings.

D) INCORRECT:

The characteristic click heard on auscultation in patients with mitral valve prolapse (MVP) results from the bulging of the valve leaflets into the atrium, which begins when the contracting left ventricle reaches a critical volume during systole. An increased left ventricular end-diastolic volume, e.g., due to increased venous return to the heart during the release phase of the Valsalva maneuver (i.e., increased preload) delays the point when that volume is reached and results in a later onset of the auscultatory findings.

E) INCORRECT:

Leaning forward brings the heart closer to the chest, but it has no significant impact on preload or afterload, so it does not affect the timing of the murmur of mitral valve prolapse. However, a pericardial friction rub and the murmur of aortic regurgitation are best heard with the patient leaning forward.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which can manifest with joint hypermobility (predisposing to joint dislocations) and hyperextensible skin. Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is associated with mitral valve prolapse (MVP), a structural defect of the mitral valves due to myxomatous degeneration that leads to the bulging of the leaflets into the left atrium during systole.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She appears well. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiac auscultation shows a mid-systolic click and a grade 3/6, late-systolic, crescendo murmur that is best heard at the cardiac apex in the left lateral recumbent position. After the patient stands up suddenly, the click is heard during early systole and the intensity of the murmur increases. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's examination findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A myosin heavy chain defect is associated with familial hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which is frequently asymptomatic and classically manifests with a heart murmur that can be intensified by standing up. However, HOCM usually presents with a mitral regurgitation systolic murmur and/or a systolic ejection murmur (crescendo-decrescendo), but not with a mid-systolic click and crescendo systolic murmur.

B) INCORRECT:

Aortic root dilation is a characteristic feature of Marfan syndrome and can lead to aortic regurgitation. However, AR would manifest with a diastolic murmur with a decrescendo best heard at the left sternal border, not with a mid-systolic click and crescendo systolic murmur heard in the mitral area. Moreover, the murmur in AR intensifies when the patient leans forward and decreases instead of increases by standing.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

C) CORRECT:

Dermatan sulfate deposition in the mitral valve leaflets, which is characteristic of myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve, is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's MVP. This condition is most commonly idiopathic but can also be associated with connective tissue disorders (e.g., Marfan syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, fragile X syndrome) or occur as a complication of infective endocarditis, rheumatic heart disease, and myocardial infarction. The mid-systolic click heard on auscultation is caused by sudden tensing of the chordae tendinae, which occurs earlier and more forcefully with decreased left ventricular size.

Maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., handgrip, squatting) are another way to help differentiate MVP from other causes of mitral insufficiency. In MVP, these maneuvers cause the click to move later in systole and become softer due to an increase in left ventricular size.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

Congenital valvular fusion is the underlying cause of bicuspid aortic valve, which is usually asymptomatic but can predispose to both aortic stenosis (AS) and aortic regurgitation. A calcified bicuspid aortic valve manifests with an aortic systolic ejection click followed by a late systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard over the 2nd right intercostal space, not with a mid-systolic click and crescendo systolic murmur heard best in the mitral area. Furthermore, the murmur in AS decreases instead of increases by sudden standing. Aortic regurgitation, in turn, presents with a murmur during diastole (not systole).

E) INCORRECT:

Congenital interventricular communication causes a ventricular septal defect, which is usually asymptomatic (if the defect is small). However, VSD manifests with a harsh holosystolic murmur over the left lower sternal border and a mid-diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex, not with a mid-systolic click and crescendo systolic murmur heard in the mitral area. In addition, the intensity of the murmur in VSD would be decreased or remain unchanged by standing up instead of increasing.
questions.hint: The presence of a mid-systolic click followed by a crescendo murmur at the mitral area (cardiac apex) is suggestive of mitral valve prolapse (MVP). Maneuvers that decrease the left ventricular size (e.g., sudden standing) increase the intensity of the murmur and cause the click to occur earlier in systole.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents for preoperative evaluation before hip arthroplasty. She reports only hip pain with no chest pain, shortness of breath, or syncope.
Physical examination reveals a high-pitched click after S1, followed by a late-systolic murmur at the apex. S2 has normal physiologic splitting. The lungs are clear, and there is no peripheral edema.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s cardiac examination findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The murmur from an atrial septal defect is classically described as a mid-systolic murmur, heard best at the left upper sternal border, related to increased blood flow through the pulmonic valve from left-to-right shunting. There is a wide, fixed splitting of S2. Given the normal respiratory splitting of S2 and the apical location of the patient’s murmur, an atrial septal defect is unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

The murmur in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy occurs with obstructive physiology. It is a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur usually heard best at the left lower sternal border without a click, which helps to distinguish it from mitral valve prolapse. The murmur increases in intensity with the Valsalva maneuver.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s physical examination findings are most consistent with mitral valve prolapse. The characteristic finding of mitral valve prolapse is a high-pitched, mid-systolic click related to tensing of the mitral valve as the mitral leaflets prolapse into the left atrium during systole. Often, as in this patient, the click is followed by a mid- or late-systolic murmur corresponding to some degree of mitral regurgitation, usually mild. The majority of patients with mitral valve prolapse have no symptoms. Although this patient is asymptomatic and does not have evidence of heart failure on examination, an echocardiogram would be recommended to confirm the diagnosis and to rule out other diagnoses that would have greater clinical implications, such as mitral regurgitation. A diagnosis of mitral valve prolapse would have no implications on this patient’s plans for surgery.

Key learning point: Mitral valve prolapse is often asymptomatic but can be identified on physical examination by a mid-systolic click.

D) INCORRECT:

The murmur of aortic regurgitation is typically an early diastolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. This patient’s murmur is present in systole, so it is not consistent with aortic regurgitation.

E) INCORRECT:

The murmur of tricuspid regurgitation is typically a holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. As with other right-sided murmurs, it usually increases with inspiration. Contrary to mitral valve prolapse, tricuspid regurgitation has no associated high-pitched sound or click.

questions.text: You are seeing a 72-year-old woman in your clinic for preoperative evaluation prior to hip arthroplasty. She reports hip pain but denies chest pain, shortness of breath, or syncope. On examination, you note a high-pitched click after S1, followed by a late-systolic murmur at the apex. S2 has normal physiologic splitting. Her lungs are clear and there is no peripheral edema. Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of her cardiac examination findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s physical examination findings are most consistent with mitral valve prolapse. The characteristic finding of mitral valve prolapse is a high-pitched, mid-systolic click related to tensing of the mitral valve as the mitral leaflets prolapse into the left atrium during systole. Often, as in this patient, the click is followed by a mid- or late-systolic murmur corresponding to some degree of mitral regurgitation, usually mild. The majority of patients with mitral valve prolapse have no symptoms. Although this patient is asymptomatic and does not have evidence of heart failure on examination, an echocardiogram would be recommended to confirm the diagnosis and to rule out other diagnoses that would have greater clinical implications, such as mitral regurgitation. A diagnosis of mitral valve prolapse would have no implications on this patient’s plans for surgery.

Key learning point: Mitral valve prolapse is often asymptomatic but can be identified on physical examination by a mid-systolic click.

B) INCORRECT:

The murmur in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy occurs with obstructive physiology. It is a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur usually heard best at the left lower sternal border without a click, which helps to distinguish it from mitral valve prolapse. The murmur increases in intensity with the Valsalva maneuver.

C) INCORRECT:

The murmur of aortic regurgitation is typically an early diastolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. This patient’s murmur is present in systole, so it is not consistent with aortic regurgitation.

D) INCORRECT:

The murmur of tricuspid regurgitation is typically a holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. As with other right-sided murmurs, it usually increases with inspiration. Contrary to mitral valve prolapse, tricuspid regurgitation has no associated high-pitched sound or click.

E) INCORRECT:

The murmur from an atrial septal defect is classically described as a mid-systolic murmur, heard best at the left upper sternal border, related to increased blood flow through the pulmonic valve from left-to-right shunting. There is a wide, fixed splitting of S2. Given the normal respiratory splitting of S2 and the apical location of the patient’s murmur, an atrial septal defect is unlikely.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine physical exam. Her medical history is unremarkable. Cardiac auscultation reveals a murmur heard best over the apex. When the patient stands up from a squatting position, the murmur intensifies and is heard earlier in systole. Which of the following is the most likely finding on cardiac examination?

choices.text: Crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border
Mid-systolic click followed by a late systolic murmur
Opening snap followed by a mid-diastolic rumble
High-pitched decrescendo diastolic murmur at the left sternal border

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This is the classic murmur of aortic stenosis. It is heard at a different location (right upper sternal border, not the apex) and has a different quality. Furthermore, the murmur of aortic stenosis decreases in intensity with maneuvers that reduce preload, such as standing. The stem describes a change in timing of a sound, not primarily a change in intensity.

B) CORRECT:

Cardiac auscultation in patients with mitral valve prolapse (MVP) typically shows a mid-systolic click followed by a mid-to-late systolic murmur best heard at the apex. The mid-systolic click is a high-pitched sound produced by the sudden tensing of the chordae tendineae as the redundant mitral leaflet billows into the left atrium during ventricular contraction. A late systolic murmur may follow if the prolapse causes mitral regurgitation. Standing from a squat decreases venous return, which reduces left ventricular volume. This smaller chamber size causes the prolapse to occur earlier in systole, moving the click closer to S1. Conversely, maneuvers that increase LV volume, like squatting, delay the click. MVP is often benign but is the most common cause of primary mitral regurgitation.

C) INCORRECT:

An opening snap followed by a mid-diastolic rumble is a typical finding heard in mitral stenosis. The opening snap is an early diastolic sound, and the rumble follows. These sounds occur during diastole, not systole, as described in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

A high-pitched decrescendo diastolic murmur at the left sternal border is the classic murmur of aortic regurgitation. This is a diastolic murmur, which is inconsistent with the systolic event described. The maneuver of standing from a squat primarily affects the timing of systolic events.
questions.hint: Maneuvers, such as the Valsalva maneuver, that decrease left ventricular volume, such as standing from a squat, cause the characteristic sound of this condition to occur earlier in systole.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman undergoes a pre-employment physical. She is asymptomatic. She has a history of mild anxiety. Her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, and her pulse is 72/min. Cardiac examination shows a sharp, high-pitched mid-systolic sound, followed by a soft murmur at the apex. The patient is asked to stand up from a squatting position. Which of the following changes is most likely to be heard on auscultation?

choices.text: The intensity of the murmur decreases
The click and murmur occur later in systole
The click and murmur occur earlier in systole

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This is the expected response for most systolic murmurs (e.g., aortic stenosis, mitral regurgitation) to maneuvers that decrease preload, as there is less blood flow across the affected valve. However, mitral valve prolapse is a key exception to this rule, as standing from a squat causes a different effect.

B) INCORRECT:

The click is a result of a mechanical event: the tensing of the chordae tendineae during leaflet prolapse. Standing from a squat decreases left ventricular volume. This maneuver would not be expected to eliminate the underlying anatomical and physiological cause of the click.

C) INCORRECT:

This finding would be expected with maneuvers that increase left ventricular (LV) preload and volume, such as squatting, a passive leg raise, or sustained handgrip. A larger LV volume takes longer to empty to the point where the mitral valve prolapses, thus delaying the click and murmur. Standing from a squat decreases LV preload, causing a different effect.

D) CORRECT:

The click in mitral valve prolapse is caused by the sudden tensing of the chordae tendineae as the redundant mitral leaflet prolapses into the left atrium during systole. Maneuvers that decrease left ventricular (LV) preload, such as standing from a squat or the strain phase of the Valsalva maneuver, reduce LV volume. A smaller LV chamber size causes the prolapse to occur sooner after the onset of ventricular contraction, moving the click and murmur earlier in systole (closer to S1) and increasing their intensity. Conversely, maneuvers that increase preload, such as squatting, delay the click and murmur.
questions.hint: This patient's findings of a midsystolic click followed by a late systolic murmur are pathognomonic for mitral valve prolapse.
